EXECUTIVE SUMMARY OF RMP
MEMC Electronic Materials, Inc.
Saint Peters, MO


40 CFR 68.155(a)
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The plant approach to chemical safety is summarized in the Corporate Environmental, Safety, and Health Policy.  "MEMC Electronic Materials will strive to achieve an injury-free and healthful workplace for our employees.  We strive to minimize effects on the surrounding environment and ensure the safety of our community neighbors, contractors and visitors."
 
MEMC 
+ is certified to the ISO14001 international environmental standard
+ has systems in place to protect employees, community, and environment
+ has emphad accident prevention at the site since its beginning in 1959
+ is a member of the St. Charles County Local Emergency Planning Committee
+ has its own trained Emergency Response Team with members onsite 24 hours a day
+ coordinates its ERT with Central County Fire and Rescue to provide rapid response to any sort of incident

Central County Fire and Rescue
+ is designated to respond to any incident that requires more capability than MEMC's first responders can provide
+ provides or recommends training for MEMC's ERT members
+ has a station is about two miles from the plant entrance
+ can have its first units arrive on site in less than five minutes


40 CFR 68.155(b)
The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The 190-acre site is MEMC's World Headquarters, employing over 800 in R&D and silicon product manufacturing for the semiconductor and solar industries.  The plant is an Intermediate Source of air emissions with Facility ID 183-0027, and holds an Intermediate Operating Permit, OP2012-043.

The overall process consists of solidifying pure molten silicon into single crystals, or slicing these crystals into wafers.  Wafers may be planarized to perfect flatness, or polished to a perfect finish in a cleanroom environment, or coated in an epitaxy process, or receive

other treatments.  All these individual process steps do not necessarily occur on site at once.

Hydrogen chloride gas stored and used in the epitaxy process ("epi" or "SOI epi") is managed under OSHA's Process Safety Management program.  EPA's Risk Management Plan regulates this hydrogen chloride usage, as well.


40 CFR 68.155(c)
General Accident Release Prevention and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

MEMC accidental release prevention for hydrogen chloride is based on the Process Safety Management standard.  Elements of the PSM program include evergreen and actively maintained written operating procedures that are followed by trained and knowledgeable technicians.
 
Over time, MEMC has built a collection of detailed process safety procedures to insure standardized chemical handling and usage. The procedures begin with a safety section to reinforce the main theme of "Safety First".  Management Of Change is formally controlled in covered processes to ensure that no unauthorized changes occur.  Job Safety Analyses or Risk Assessments are also used as applicable, to identify hazards, and control risks.  These are step-by-step reviews of tasks to ensure these jobs are done according to the safety standard.

Prevention steps include:
+ Tank and vessel inspection program to check mechanical integrity
+ Safety relief valve test program to ensure equipment functions as designed
+ Process Line Entry Permit for servicing piping and equipment and returning it to service
+ Hot Work Permits, Fire Prevention Plans, and related procedures
+ Sprinkler systems and firewalls to minimize the threat of fire or explosion

MEMC measures the Serious Incident Rate for the plant each month, to include all accidents and incidents and potential incidents, not simply injuries.  Those classified as Serious Incidents are formally investigated, and tracked in a Corrective Action Request system.  Safety work order and safety suggestion programs provide all employees with t

he opportunity to participate in finding and reporting barriers to safety.

MEMC uses a formal Chemical Registration process that will not allow any new chemical substance in the plant unless it has received proper review for safe use, storage, and eventual disposal.  Chemical usage is tracked by month, by chemical, by department.


40 CFR 68.155(d)
Five-Year Accident History

Within five years of the date of this revision, there have been no releases of any regulated substance above the threshold quantity from a covered process.

So there is no information available about deaths, injuries, property damages, environmental damages, evacuations, or sheltering in place, because none of these occurred in the five-year period.

Also, none have occurred during the 54 years the facility has been in operation.


40 CFR 68.155(e)
Emergency Response Program 

All employees are trained to dial the Plant Emergency Hotline from any plant telephone in case of a chemical release, fire, or medical emergency of any kind.  That emergency number is also posted on all plant telephones.  The Hotline and the plant's emergency alarms go to the security desk in the main lobby.  The security officers activate the site Emergency Response Team paging system and will summon other plant resources, including Central County Fire and Rescue when needed.

The response is handled by the plant's Emergency Response Team, and Central County Fire and Rescue when necessary.  MEMC ERT members are 40-hour HazWoper trained and given refresher training annually.  Emergency Medical Responder training has also been provided. Periodically, MEMC's ERT and Central County Fire and Rescue review emergency responses and plans, and conduct joint training exercises.
 

In the event of an emergency with off-site consequences, MEMC would work with Central County Fire and Rescue.  CCFR would adhere to the National Incident Command System, summon and coordinate any other necessary resources includin

g medical response, law enforcement, and hazmat teams from a multi-county area, and determine whether to evacuate off-site locations, shelter in place, or implement other actions.


40 CFR 68.155(f)
Planned Changes to Improve Safety

In addition to the maintaining the prevention program elements described above, MEMC may conduct the following activities to further improve safety at the site:

+ Additional safety and emergency response training
+ Implementation of behavioral safety programs
+ Certification to the OHSAS18001 occupational health and safety standard
+ Continued improvement of the PSM program elements

[end]
